intro: Tomanthea carthamoides, commonly known as the yellow wood sorrel, is a flowering plant native to parts of Africa and the Middle East. It belongs to the family Asteraceae, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant produces small, yellow flowers that bloom in clusters, often accompanied by heart-shaped leaves with a distinctive waxy coating. Tomanthea carthamoides is typically found in arid or semi-arid environments, thriving in well-drained soils. It is sometimes cultivated for ornamental purposes due to its attractive foliage and flowers.
